column2: How did you get into comedy?I think I fell into it. It was a night out with the comedy society at my university and we all got up and gave it a go. It went well enough that when I moved to London I thought: â€œWhy not? You seem to have a knack for this.â€ And here I still am! Who did you look up to when you were first starting out?I remember loving Kitty Flanagan. She is back in Australia now being amazing, but some might remember her from The Sketch Show on ITV. There werenâ€™t a lot of women to aspire to at the time and she was just a natural. Mandy Knight was another who could MC the midnight show at the Comedy Store better than any of the men. What did you spend lockdown doing?I spent lockdown with my family and kids, just taking it easy. I live in London as a self-employed standup comedian; the pace I live and work at is insane. The lockdown was because of health one way or another, so I decided to use the forced sabbatical to be as healthy as I could before the world reopened and we all got back on this merry-go-round on speed weâ€™re all riding. Do you think audiences have changed since lockdown?I donâ€™t think audiences have changed because of lockdown. I think they are evolving because of a general growing awareness and respect of others. The range of people doing comedy is more diverse and the audienceâ€™s tastes are reflecting that. They are more comedy savvy than ever, and they have higher expectations. Can you recall a gig so bad, itâ€™s now funny?When I was starting out, I did a song called The Coming Song and I was invited to play a gig on Mothering Sunday for a group of people who, unbeknownst to me, had been invited to bring their mothers to the free gig straight from church. The song did not go well. Those there without their mothers loved it. Those with their mothers didnâ€™t know where to look. Whatâ€™s an important lesson youâ€™ve learned from being a standup?Not to take life too seriously. They say: comedy = tragedy + time. Of course, this doesnâ€™t apply to everyone. If youâ€™re prime minister, for example, this is not the advice for you. Best heckle?In the middle of my Live at the Apollo, someone yelled out, â€œI love you!â€ apropos of nothing. And that was very funny at the time. Best advice youâ€™ve ever been given?They donâ€™t know how shit you are so donâ€™t walk on like youâ€™re shit. Learning to fake it until you make it is invaluable in comedy. A lot of newer male comics are great at this, whereas women tend to wear their newness and honesty on their sleeves. Audiences donâ€™t assume youâ€™re new or rubbish until your insecurities reveal you feel that way. Best advice you ever give?Donâ€™t eat yellow snow. My mother told me that as a joke when I was very young, but as I had never seen snow at that point I thought this was serious advice. Years later I now equate this to: donâ€™t shit where you eat â€“ I think this is prudent, regardless of the weather. You used to perform with a ukulele. Will it ever return?Never say never. I canâ€™t unlearn how to play and sing so why wouldnâ€™t it? Ria Lina is in Lovestruck High on Amazon Prime.

column2: EasyJet plans to remove seats in some of its planes this summer as part of a strategy to cut the number of staff it needs. Employers across the economy have complained of difficulty recruiting staff at the salaries they are willing to pay, and airlines are struggling to meet the increased demand as international travel restarts in earnest after Covid-19 lockdowns. Airlines are required by law to provide one member of cabin crew for every 50 seats. By removing the final row of six seats on its smallest plane, the A319, easyJet will cut the number of passengers it can carry from 156 to 150, therefore limiting its requirement to three rather than four cabin crew. Airport and airline bosses are looking to hire thousands of staff to cope with what is expected to be a summer holiday boom, as many international destinations reopen to tourists from countries including the UK. The UK government removed restrictions on international travel in January. Johan Lundgren, the easyJet chief executive, has previously said the company expects to reach near 2019 levels of passenger numbers this summer, despite recent problems with getting security clearance for new recruits. EasyJet was already forced to cancel hundreds of flights over the Easter holiday period, which it blamed on staff sickness during a wave of Covid-19 infections in the UK. Airlines are particularly keen to avoid staffing problems because they can be liable for steep compensation bills for cancellations within two weeks of the departure date. Airlines are generally considered liable for staff shortages. â€œThis summer we will be operating our UK A319 fleet with a maximum of 150 passengers onboard and three crew in line with CAA regulations,â€ easyJet said in a statement. â€œThis is an effective way of operating our fleet while building additional resilience and flexibility into our operation this summer where we expect to be back to near 2019 levels of flying.â€

column2: Ispend a considerable amount of my time searching for moments of peace. This is partly the result of the world we live in: weâ€™re locked into a 24/7 society, where being overstimulated is the norm. But it also speaks to personal contradictions: I have a never-ending to-do list that propels me through each day, every action a task to be ticked off, from eating lunch to walking to the shop. For someone who desires tranquillity so much, I donâ€™t leave much room for it. Clearly, Iâ€™m not alone in this quest. Much has been made of the relentless cultural march of â€œmindfulnessâ€, a concept originating as a meditative practice but now seemingly used to refer to anything from paying nearly Â£70 annually for an app to wild swimming. Too many column inches have already been devoted to dissecting the prevalence of mindfulness, but suffice to say I see its elevation into a mainstream fixture (and its subsequent commodification) as one symptom of a mass search for a little pocket of peace. Last year I worked on a podcast episode for the Wellcome Collection to go with an exhibition it was presenting that was partly devoted to the concept of tranquillity. Chatting with a contributor, the environmental psychologist Dr Eleanor Ratcliffe, I reeled off a list of places in my adopted home, London, where Iâ€™d experienced the feeling of transcending my grubby little self and being flooded with utter peace: the tippy-top of St Paulâ€™s cathedral; the Watts Memorial in Postmanâ€™s Park; a medieval church tucked away on Ely Place, one of the cityâ€™s last privately managed roads. There was a common thread there, Ratcliffe told me, citing the work of her PhD student Ruairi Patterson: awe, that transcendent feeling of reverence and wonder that might be sparked by a particularly fiery sunset, or watching your friend stuff four hotdogs in her mouth at once. â€‹â€‹I was intrigued by this and reached out to Patterson. Yes, he told me, there is growing evidence that experiencing awe can reduce stress and improve wellbeing. Patterson pointed me to a paper published last year, led by a researcher at Peking University, which found that experiencing â€œawe-inspiring phenomenaâ€ could lead to greater life satisfaction and less stress. Previous work has also suggested that experiencing awe is a key part of natureâ€™s ability to decrease stress levels and improve wellbeing. â€œThese effects,â€ says Patterson, â€œresult at least in part from the ability of awe-inspiring experiences to â€˜put things in perspectiveâ€™ by making oneself and oneâ€™s personal concerns seem small in comparison to the perceived vastness of awe-inspiring phenomena.â€ A beautiful idea, isnâ€™t it? Yes, I thought, awe certainly plays a central role in when I feel most serene. But giving it some thought, Iâ€™m sure itâ€™s not the only factor; there are plenty of times I have felt awe and yet not quite achieved that state of peace. After consideration, Iâ€™ve come up with an alternate thesis: itâ€™s about being out of context. The occasions I feel most peaceful is when I have stepped out of the normal flow of my daily life and into someone elseâ€™s timeline. Like heading into a church as a non-believer, with no religious tradition in my past. Cycling through a park I never usually visit. Eating lunch in the cafe of a museum instead of reheating my salmon and veg at home. When I am out of context, my problems are unable to find me until Iâ€™ve slipped back into the rhythms of my normal existence. The more Iâ€™ve thought about this, the more it feels correct. I remember the great sense of peace that would wash over me as a child when I was taken out of school in the middle of the day for a doctorâ€™s appointment. Sitting on the hard, plastic, waiting-room chairs, I would hear the shouts of my peers in the nearby school playground and feel utterly calm that I was not there with them, in my proper place. Itâ€™s a comforting mix of quasi-anonymity, novelty, and escape from the flotsam that accrues by simply existing. By its nature, finding tranquillity by stepping out of myself isnâ€™t a lasting way of being. It is a state that can be snatched at; at some point I have to snap back into place. I suspect being constantly at peace would breed complacency. Having to strive for something, even if itâ€™s inner calm, sadly means I value it more. At least armed with the knowledge of exactly what conditions create that sense of serenity means it feels within reach. That alone is soothing. And I did it without the help of a mindfulness app. Saving Â£70 on self-knowledge: now thatâ€™s peace. Moya Lothian-McLean is a journalist who writes about politics and digital culture
column4: Moments of peace amid hectic lives are possible. We just need to know where to look | Moya Lothian-McLean

column2: There is one rule behind every movie poster you have ever seen. And itâ€™s not: â€œSuperheroes must stare determinedly into the distance.â€ It is this: the billing block, the list of cast and crew at the bottom, must be in a typeface that is at least 15% of the size of the film titleâ€™s lettering. In 2005, when he was leading the advertising campaign for the Jim Carrey comedy Fun With Dick and Jane, William Loper didnâ€™t like that. The guideline, which is there to ensure billings are actually legible, annoyed Loper because it meant that if he wanted to make a filmâ€™s title larger and more eye-catching, he had to make the billing block larger too. But the then executive vice-president of advertising at Sony Pictures spotted a loophole. It was the average height of each letter in the title that counted. So he made just one word in the Carrey comedyâ€™s title huge and bright red: FUN. â€œWe cheated,â€ he says. But why? Well, between 2003 and 2013, Loper launched eight campaigns a year, each having to be as grabby as possible. And when it came to advertising comedies, there were two big typography tricks: make the title big, and make it red. When the trailer for Catherine Tateâ€™s The Nan Movie dropped in February this year, its title was big and red. Disneyâ€™s Cheaper By the Dozen remake, which followed shortly after, has its final word in thick, ruddy, bloated type. Whatâ€™s more, both posters â€“ like Fun With Dick and Jane â€“ have vast white backgrounds. So, who started the big red titles on empty backgrounds trend and why is it red that tickles our funny bones? No one is better placed to answer this than Loper, who also worked on The Nutty Professor, Are We There Yet?, The Klumps, Liar, Liar, Step Brothers, Hitch and American Pie. By now, I donâ€™t need to tell you how their posters look. â€œThe white background, red typography,â€ he says, â€œreally thrived in the mid-90s and early 2000s.â€ As part of his job, Loper showed prototype trailers to test audiences. â€œWe did the teaser trailer for Nutty Professor and it said, â€˜Something big is comingâ€™ â€“ and then we slammed on those big titles. That was a huge hit in the focus groups.â€ Because producers and even stars get a say on a filmâ€™s advertising, research like this can help execs prove they are on the right track. But there is no one study that says: â€œRed equals comedy, big letters equal big money.â€ Instead, there is the humble bus shelter. Loper explains: â€œA producer I used to work with would constantly tell me: â€˜If Iâ€™m driving down the street at 40mph and itâ€™s raining, I want to see a bus shelter poster that has impact. I want to see it from eight blocks away.â€™â€ Empty backgrounds help a filmâ€™s star pop out, while red is red. Thereâ€™s a reason why it is the colour of stop signs and classic lipsticks. In the past, when billboards and bus shelter ads were printed on paper, advertisers had to get the campaign right first time. â€œBut now,â€ says Loper, â€œyou can change a digital billboard every other day. Thatâ€™s really helped.â€ Poster designer Rebecca Pitt explains that, 30 years ago, the tech was more limited. â€œBig red letters were easy to do, whereas 3D metallic lettering only became easy 15 or so years ago.â€ The latter, she says, has become the default in theatre posters for plays such as Anything Goes and AmÃ©lie. Although Pitt has used big red letters herself in a couple of theatre posters: Groan Ups and The Comedy About a Bank Robbery. â€œThese are very accessible shows that appeal to families,â€ she says. â€œThe big red letters help to signify that. We want to reassure audiences that thisâ€™ll be a fun evening out â€“ nothing too highbrow or alternative.â€ But every campaign wants to be eye-catching and appealing. Why did comedy get a monopoly on big and red â€“ and not, say, action movies or thrillers? Robyn Larkin is the creative director of the film poster agency Bobo, which worked on Winterâ€™s Bone and Netflixâ€™s Paranormal. He describes it as â€œa sort of chicken and egg situationâ€ whereby marketers became obsessed with â€œcompsâ€ (comparisons) and would ask designers to emulate other successful campaigns. He describes the situation as â€œa sort of fake myth, where they think that if the promotional look worked well for film A then it will also work for film Bâ€. He cites 1999â€™s American Pie and 2000â€™s Meet the Parents as hits that inspired copycat marketing. â€œYet American Pie worked because it was a great new sort of film.â€ Its success probably had little to do with typefaces. Loper believes big type and blank backgrounds started in the late 1980s. So did Honey, I Shrunk the Kids father the whole thing in 1989? Perhaps not: despite its blue-sky background, 1980â€™s Airplane! was an earlier example. What about the Carry On posters of the 1960s, which liberally employed big red type alongside saucy cartoons? In fact, you can trace the trend all the way back to 1937 and the Marx Brothersâ€™ A Day at the Races, even to Charlie Chaplinâ€™s The Kid from 1921. While comedies at the turn of the millennium undoubtedly caused a resurgence, the trick is almost as old as cinema itself â€“ and it seems unlikely to be going away. â€œOne day,â€ says Larkin, â€œthere will be a big comedy hit that uses a different style because the team took a risk and it worked. That style may then become the next trope as marketing people across the land copy the style, looking to ride the filmâ€™s success.â€ Perhaps the opposite could happen. With a solid 0% on Rotten Tomatoes, The Nan Movie might put the big and red to bed.

column2: Ithought I had already experienced the worst internet abuse â€“ until I posted online about my dog, Hank. I had been wondering if I should take him to the vet, after finding some scary-looking lumps on his chest. When I got Hank, I thought I was vigorously prepared. I had done all the research, bought all the gear, hired a trainer, forked out for pet insurance and found a great vet. I had every intention of being the best dog owner ever. I was ready. What I was not prepared for was the pressure from other dog owners to never make mistakes. On one level, this is a good thing: I want people to have high standards for pet owners. Animals should be treated well. However, if I wanted constantly to be made to feel like Iâ€™m not good enough, I would still be living at home. When Hank shat all over a hotel staircase, the stench wasnâ€™t nearly as bad as the looks that people gave me, glaring as if I had kept him in my room for days, feeding him onions and chocolate, just to make him defecate and ruin everyoneâ€™s visit to the breakfast buffet. I got the same reaction when his retractable dog lead failed at the same time as he spotted a squirrel and he circled a couple holding hands (twice), tying them together. Onlookers might have been less judgmental if I had just told them that I had trained him to kidnap couples. â€œThose leads are dangerous!â€ a woman hissed. When I posted in a Facebook group, asking for advice about the scary-looking lumps, I was inundated with vile comments. Apparently, I donâ€™t deserve to care for a dog â€“ or even be alive â€“ if I donâ€™t know that boy dogs also have nipples.  Sofie Hagen is a writer and comedian

column2: There is growing scrutiny over the Alan Tudgeâ€™s disappearance on the campaign trail as the education minister shuns the media. With just two weeks to go until election day, Tudge has not addressed the media once, has announced no education policy and has ignored repeated requests for interviews. He has also declined to debate the oppositionâ€™s education spokesperson Tanya Plibersek. Instead, the minister has been running a hyperlocal campaign, focused on community appearances and funding for projects in his electorate of Aston, in Melbourneâ€™s east. In December Tudge stepped aside from the education portfolio after allegations were made that he had had an abusive relationship with a former staffer, whom he was having an affair with. Tudge denies the allegations. Stuart Robert is currently acting education minister, but officials confirmed in Senate estimates in April that Tudge will officially remain as the education minister despite claiming he would not return to the frontbench. He also remains in cabinet. The only policies announced by Tudge during this election, however, involve upgrading key roads around Knox, in his electorate. He has promised $300,000 to put lights in both the baseball park in Boronia and Guy Turner Reserve and he also pledged $1.5m for a Hindu community hub at The Basin temple. According to his social media accounts, Tudge has spent the campaign visiting local sporting clubs and businesses but has avoided the scrutiny of media. His own website shows his last interview was on 12 October last year on Sky News. The Liberal party campaign headquarters, Tudgeâ€™s electorate office, and his media representative, ignored requests from Guardian Australia for a five-minute phone interview with the MP. No written statement was provided. Throughout the election, Tudge has posted videos of himself visiting places around Knox â€“ all with a focus on local issues. CCTV cameras, the local Headspace and sporting clubs have featured in clips on his social media. The messaging is all local, with no mention of the education portfolio. â€œWe have achieved a lot together locally, including the biggest ever injection of funds for roads, rail, car parking and bridges,â€ he said announcing his re-election campaign. â€œWe have improved security, upgraded dozens of local sports grounds, record funding into every local school and hospital, and so much more. â€œNationally, we have kept the economy strong and the country secure. We have record low unemployment, record funding for schools, hospitals and medicines and massively boosted defence spending.â€ He holds the electorate with a 10% margin, making it almost impossible for Labor to pick up the seat. But the Labor candidate for Aston, Mary Doyle, said the mood was shifting in the electorate. â€œAs Iâ€™ve been talking to residents across Aston, the mood has been quite positive towards Labor and simultaneously increasingly negative towards the Liberals and particularly Alan Tudge,â€ Doyle said. â€œAlan Tudge and Scott Morrison are alike â€“ when the going gets tough they disappear.â€ She accused Tudge of being absent from the community from last year. â€œHis ongoing absence since last year has been made even more apparent by Laborâ€™s active team on the ground, talking to locals about what matters to them,â€ Doyle said. â€œLabor has a plan to address their concerns by strengthening Medicare, making childcare cheaper, creating secure local jobs, and investing in local manufacturing.â€ The New Liberalsâ€™ candidate Ryan Bruce, who is running on a platform of net zero by 2030 and a federal Icac, said he had not seen the sitting MP on the campaign trail. â€œThe notable thing is the absence of Tudge. I havenâ€™t seen him, I havenâ€™t found a single person who said theyâ€™ve seen him,â€ Bruce said. Bruce concedes Tudge will probably hold on to the electorate, but questions whether the constituents deserve better. â€œHe is taking it for granted. I donâ€™t think heâ€™s been a great member for the seat.â€ Avoiding tough questions does not mean his campaign has been smooth-sailing. Two weeks ago several of the MPâ€™s signs were vandalised with the words â€œscumâ€, â€œIcacâ€ and â€œWomenâ€ with an X covering his face. Tudge responded with a statement posted to his Facebook, saying the damage was â€œthe work of [his] opponentsâ€. â€œThis is the work of my opponents and says more about them and what they represent than anything else,â€ he wrote. â€œThey should be on notice though: three have already been caught by police and will soon have criminal records. Thanks to those residents who recorded them. â€œI wonâ€™t be deterred by these cowards. In fact, they only encourage me and my team to work harder.â€

column2: The national disability insurance scheme minister, Linda Reynolds, has played down the surge in people filing legal appeals against cuts to funding packages, saying that the amount is still a â€œminusculeâ€ proportion of overall participants. The latest statistics, released on Friday, show the number of people appealing NDIS decisions to the administrative appeals tribunal increased by 244% in the March quarter, compared with the same period in 2021. In a rare interview during the election campaign, Reynolds was asked what she would do to address the growing number of people â€œgoing to the courts so they can get the support they needâ€. The host of the â€œReasonable and Necessaryâ€ podcast, the disability rights advocate Dr George Taleporos, said he had been â€œshockedâ€ by the increase and noted the process could be â€œvery traumaticâ€ and â€œquite expensiveâ€. â€œItâ€™s obviously very topical at the moment,â€ Reynolds said. â€œI think the context of this is really important â€¦ Remembering weâ€™ve got half a million people now on the scheme, the overall percentage of people who are going through to the AAT appeals process is still minuscule. â€œAnd most of those people who do go to the AAT, well over 90% of those are settled as part of the early AAT process. Itâ€™s important that people have an avenue to appeal to the AAT â€¦ Again itâ€™s a tiny fraction, still. â€œBecause weâ€™ve gone up to half a million [participants] now, proportionally youâ€™d expect the numbers going to the AAT would correspondingly increase.â€ The latest NDIA quarterly report said on Friday there were 4,265 open AAT cases at March 2022, compared with 518,668 participants in the scheme. However, while the number of AAT appeals made up 0.42% of all participants in March 2021, that has risen to 1.24% in the latest March quarter. Specifically, the report showed there were 1,583 cases in the March quarter, a 244% increase on the 460 cases in the 2021 March quarter.
